translated: Middle Length Discourses
With Vasettha
Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.🔽Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇamahāsālā icchānaṅgale paṭivasanti, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgala vana saṇḍe  tena kho pana samayena sambahulāḥ abhiññātāḥ abhiññātāḥ brāhmaṇa mahā sālāḥ icchānaṅgale paṭivasanti
translated: Once the Blessed One was staying at Icchanangala, in the forest of Ingudi trees.

original: caṅkī brāhmaṇo, tārukkho brāhmaṇo, pokkharasāti brāhmaṇo, jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo, todeyyo brāhmaṇo, aññe ca abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇamahāsālā.
analyzed: caṅkī brāhmaṇo tārukkhaḥ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti brāhmaṇaḥ jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo todeyyaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ aññe ca abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇa mahāsālā
translated: Now on that occasion many well-known Brahmins were staying at Icchanangala, such as the Brahmins Chan-kya, Tarukkha, Pokkharasati, Jana-suni, Todeyya, and other well-known Brahmins.

original: Atha kho vāseṭṭhabhāradvājānaṁ māṇavānaṁ jaṅghāvihāraṁ anucaṅkamantānaṁ anuvicarantānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
analyzed: atha khalu vāseṭṭha bhāradvājānam māṇavānam jaṅghāvihāram anucaṅkamantānam anuvicarantānam ayam antarākathā udapādi
translated: As Vasettha and Bharadvaja were walking and wandering for exercise, this discussion arose between them:
“How does one become a Brahmin?”
Bharadvaja said:

original: “yato kho, bho, ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṁsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena—
analyzed: yatas kho bho ubhatas sujātaḥ mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca sa suddha gahaṇikaḥ yāva sattamā pitāmaha yugā akkhittaḥ an upakkuṭṭhaḥ jāti vādena
translated: “When a man is well-born on both sides, of pure maternal and paternal descent back to the seventh paternal ancestor, unaccused and unimpeached as regards his ancestry,

analyzed: ettāvatā khalu bho brāhmaṇaḥ hoti iti
translated: that is how one becomes a Brahmin.”
Vāseṭṭha said this:

original: “yato kho, bho, sīlavā ca hoti vattasampanno ca—
analyzed: yatas kho bho sīlavā ca hoti vatta sampanno ca
translated: “When someone is virtuous and has good conduct,

analyzed: ettāvatā khalu bho brāhmaṇaḥ hoti iti
translated: that’s how a brahmin becomes a brahmin.”

original: Neva kho asakkhi bhāradvājo māṇavo vāseṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ saññāpetuṁ, na pana asakkhi vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhāradvājaṁ māṇavaṁ saññāpetuṁ.
analyzed: na iva kho asakkhi bhāradvājaḥ māṇavaḥ vāseṭṭham māṇavam saññāpetu na pana asakkhi vāseṭṭhaḥ māṇavaḥ bhāradvājam māṇavam saññāpetu
translated: But neither was able to convince the other.

original: Atha kho vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhāradvājaṁ māṇavaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha khalu vāseṭṭhaḥ māṇavaḥ bhāradvājam māṇavam āmantesi
translated: Vāseṭṭha then said to Bhāradvāja,

original: “ayaṁ kho, bho bhāradvāja, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.
analyzed: ayam kho bho bhāradvāja samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ sakya putto sakya kulā pabbajitaḥ icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgala vana saṇḍe
translated: “Bhāradvāja, the ascetic Gotama, the son of the Sakyans who went forth from the Sakyan clan, is staying in Icchānaṅgala in the Icchānaṅgala jungle thicket.

original: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
analyzed: tam kha pana bhavantam gotamam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ
translated: He has this good reputation:

original: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
analyzed: iti pi saḥ bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampanno sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā ati
translated: ‘He is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, perfect in knowledge and conduct, a Happy One, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed trainer of those who can be trained, a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, a Fortunate One.’

original: Āyāma, bho bhāradvāja, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ etamatthaṁ pucchissāma.
analyzed: āyāma bho bhāradvāja yena samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ tena upasaṅkamissāmaḥ upasaṅkamitvā samaṇam gotamam etam attham pucchissāma
translated: “Come, let’s go to the contemplative Gotama and ask him about this matter.

original: Yathā no samaṇo gotamo byākarissati tathā naṁ dhāressāmā”ti.
analyzed: yathā naḥ samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ byākarissati tathā nam dhāressāma ati
translated: We will remember it according to how the contemplative Gotama responds.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho bhāradvājo māṇavo vāseṭṭhassa māṇavassa paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhoti kho bhāradvājaḥ māṇavaḥ vāseṭṭhassa māṇavassa paccassosi
translated: Responding, “As you say, sir,” to Vasettha,

original: Atha kho vāseṭṭhabhāradvājā māṇavā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu.
analyzed: atha khalu vāseṭṭha bhāradvājāḥ māṇavāḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodisu
translated: the brahmin student Bhāradvāja went to the Blessed One and, on arrival, exchanged courteous greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
translated: After an exchange of friendly greetings & courtesies, he sat to one side.

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhagavantaṁ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho vāseṭṭhaḥ māṇavaḥ bhagavantam gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi
translated: As he was sitting there, the brahmin student Vasettha addressed the Blessed One with this verse:
“We are approved & acknowledged,
we who are masters of the three Vedas.
I am a student of Pokkharasati,🔽and this student of Tagarasikhī.
We are masters of the three Vedas,
complete in their recitation,
in the language, the rituals, and the oral tradition.
We are teachers of the Vedas,🔽equal to our teacher in recitation.
There is a dispute, Gotama.
“One is a brahmin by birth,
Bhāradvāja says;
But I say by action,

original: evaṁ jānāhi cakkhuma.🔽Te na sakkoma ñāpetuṁ,
analyzed: evam jānāhi cakkhuma  te na sakkoma ñāpetu
translated: Know this, O Visionary.🔽We are not able to convince each other,
We both;
We have come to ask you,
The one renowned as the Buddha.

analyzed: candam yathā khayā atīta  pecca pañjalikā janā
translated: Just as people with hands raised in reverence,🔽After the moon has set,
Worship and revere it,🔽So in the world they do with Gotama.
The eye has arisen in the world,
We ask Gotama;
Is one a brahmin by birth,
Or by action?
Please tell us who do not know,
So that we may know a brahmin.”
“I will explain to you,
(The Fortunate One said to Vāseṭṭha)
In due course, as it really is;
The classification of beings,
The different kinds of birth.
Know even grass and trees,
But they do not admit it;
Their birth is by signs,

original: aññamaññā hi jātiyo.🔽Tato kīṭe paṭaṅge ca,
analyzed: aññamaññāḥ hi jātiyaḥ  tatas kīṭe paṭaṅge ca
translated: For the different kinds of birth.🔽Then insects and moths,
Up to ants and termites;
Their sex is due to their species,
for their species are different from each other.
Know that among the quadrupeds,
the small and the large,
Their sex is due to their species,
for their species are different from each other.
Know that among the snakes,
the long-bodied ones,
Their sex is due to their species,
for their species are different from each other.

analyzed: tatas mat śepi jānātha  udake vāri gocare
translated: Then know that among the fish,🔽in the water, the range of the waters,
Their sex is due to their species,
for their species are different from each other.

analyzed: tatas pakkhīpi jānātha  patta yāne vihaṅgame
translated: Then know that among the birds,🔽the winged creatures that fly through the air,
Their sex is due to their species,
for their species are different from each other.
Just as in these species
the sex is varied and due to the species,
So among humans there is no such thing

original: liṅgaṁ jātimayaṁ puthu.🔽Na kesehi na sīsehi,🔽na kaṇṇehi na akkhīhi;
analyzed: liṅgam jāti mayam puthu  na kesehi na sīsehi  na kaṇṇehi na akkhīhi
translated: as a varied sex due to the species.🔽Not by the head, not by the hair,🔽not by the ears, not by the eyes,
not by the mouth, not by the nose,

original: na oṭṭhehi bhamūhi vā.🔽Na gīvāya na aṁsehi,🔽na udarena na piṭṭhiyā;
analyzed: na oṭṭhehi bhamūhi vā  na gīvāya na asehi  na udarena na piṭṭhiyā
translated: not by the cheeks, not by the brows.🔽Not by the neck, not by the shoulders,🔽not by the belly, not by the back,
not by the genitals, not by the chest,
not by the sides, not by the buttocks.
Not by the hands, not by the feet,
With fingers or with nails,
With shanks or with thighs,
With complexion or with voice,
No sign of birth is there,
As in other kinds of birth.
And in individual bodies,
This is not found among humans.
And the variation among humans,
Is declared by common consent.
Whoever among humans
Subsists by protecting cattle,
Thus, Vasettha, you should know
He is a farmer, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans
Subsists by a particular craft,
Thus, Vasettha, you should know
He is a craftsman, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans
Subsists by trade,
Thus, Vasettha, you should know
He is a trader, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans
Subsists by being another’s servant,
Thus, Vasettha, you should know
He is a servant, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans
Subsists by taking what is not given,
Thus, Vasettha, you should know
He is a thief, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans
Subsists by the bow,
Know this, Vasettha,
the warrior is not a brahmin.
Whoever among men
lives by the priestly office,
Know this, Vasettha,
the priest is not a brahmin.
Whoever among men
enjoys the village and the kingdom,
Know this, Vasettha,

original: rājā eso na brāhmaṇo.🔽Na cāhaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ brūmi,🔽yonijaṁ mattisambhavaṁ;
analyzed: rājā esaḥ na brāhmaṇaḥ  na ca aham brāhmaṇam brūmi  yoni jam matti sambhava
translated: the king is not a brahmin.🔽I do not call a man a brahmin🔽because of his mother or father,
or because he is of pure descent for many generations,

original: sace hoti sakiñcano;🔽Akiñcanaṁ anādānaṁ,🔽tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
analyzed: sace hoti sakiñcanaḥ  akiñcanam an ādāna  tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa
translated: if he is full of greed.🔽But I call a brahmin
one who is free from all fetters,
who is not agitated,
who has cut off all the fetters,🔽who is free from all suffering.

original: tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Chetvā naddhiṁ varattañca,🔽sandānaṁ sahanukkamaṁ;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  chetvā naddhim varattam ca  sandānam sahanukkama
translated: I call a brahmin🔽one who has cut the strap and the tether,
the yoke and the reins,🔽the one who has lifted the burden, the enlightened one.

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  akkosam vadha bandham ca
translated: I call a brahmin
one who is not angry,
who is patient with abuse, beating, and bondage,🔽who has the strength of patience.

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  akkodhanam vatavanta
translated: I call a brahmin🔽one who is not angry,🔽who is virtuous,
who is not arrogant,
Whose teeth are not broken, whose body is not bent,
I call him a brahmin.
Like a lotus is unsoiled by water,
like a needle by rice,
He who is not soiled by sensual pleasures,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yaḥ dukkhassa pajānāti
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽He who understands right here
the destruction of suffering for himself,
Who has laid down the burden, is unfettered,
I call him a brahmin.
The one with deep wisdom, the wise one,
skilled in what is the path and not the path,
Who has attained the highest goal,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  a sasaṭṭham gahaṭṭhehi  anāgārehi
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽Not associating with householders,🔽with those gone forth, with both,
Who lives without a house, is content,
I call him a brahmin.
Having laid aside the rod against beings,
against frail and feeble creatures,

analyzed: yaḥ na hanti na ghātā iti
translated: Who does not kill or get others to kill,
I call him a brahmin.

analyzed: a viruddham viruddhesu  atta daṇḍesu nibbuta
translated: Not opposing those who oppose,🔽being peaceful among those who wield weapons,
Not grasping at what is pleasing,
I call him a brahmin.
He in whom passion, hatred,
conceit, and contempt are destroyed,
Like a needle by rice,
I call him a brahmin.
Who speaks words that are not harsh,
Who speaks the truth,
By which he does not offend anyone,

original: tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Yo ca dīghaṁ va rassaṁ vā,🔽aṇuṁ thūlaṁ subhāsubhaṁ;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yaḥ ca dīgham va rassam vā  aṇum thūlam subha asubha
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One who does not take what is not given,🔽Whether long or short, small or large, beautiful or ugly,
In this world,
I call him a brahmin.
One who has no desires
In this world or the next,
Free from desires, unattached,

original: tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Yassālayā na vijjanti,🔽aññāya akathaṅkathiṁ;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  na vijjanti  aññāya a kathaṅkathi
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One who has no abode,🔽Having understood, not wavering,
Having attained the deathless state,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yodha puññañca pāpañca
translated: I call him a brahmin.
One who has gone beyond both merit and demerit,🔽Having crossed over the flood that is hard to cross,
Griefless, dust-free, pure,

original: tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Candaṁ va vimalaṁ suddhaṁ,🔽vippasannaṁ anāvilaṁ;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  candam va vimalam suddha  vippasannam anāvila
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One who is like the spotless, pure moon,🔽Clear, unclouded,
Who has destroyed delight and existence,

original: tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Yo imaṁ palipathaṁ duggaṁ,🔽saṁsāraṁ mohamaccagā;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yaḥ imam palipatham dugga  sasāram moham acca gā
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One who has crossed over this swamp, this difficult place,

analyzed: tiṇṇaḥ pāraṅgataḥ jhāyī  an ejaḥ a kathaṅkathī
translated: This cycle of existence, overcome by delusion,🔽The meditator who has crossed over and gone beyond,🔽Unwavering, not wavering,
Extinguished through non-clinging,
I call him a brahmin.
Having given up the desire for battle,
wandering without a home,
having destroyed the existence of sensual pleasures,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yodha taṇham pahantvāna  anāgāraḥ paribbaje
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽Having given up craving for battle,🔽wandering without a home,
having destroyed the existence of craving,
I call him a brahmin.
Having given up human bonds,
having gone beyond divine bonds,
free from all bonds,
I call him a brahmin.
Having given up delight and disliking,
having become cool, free from attachments,
the hero who has overcome the whole world,
I call him a brahmin.
One who knows the passing away
and rebirth of all beings,
the one without attachment, the one gone to bliss, the enlightened one,

original: tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Yassa gatiṁ na jānanti,
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yassa gatim na jānanti
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One whose destination
the gods, gandhabbas, and humans do not know,
the one with taints destroyed, the perfected one,

original: tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Yassa pure ca pacchā ca,🔽majjhe ca natthi kiñcanaṁ;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yassa pure ca pacchā ca  majjhe ca natthi kiñcana
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One who has nothing at all🔽in the past, future, or present,
the one without anything, the one without grasping,
I call him a brahmin.
The bull, the supreme hero,
The Great Seer, the Victorious One,
The Buddha, the One of Steady Wisdom, the One of Steady Wisdom, the One of Steady Wisdom,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  pubbenivāsam yaḥ vedi
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One who knows their past lives,
Who sees heaven and the fall,
And has attained the destruction of birth,
I call him a brahmin.
This is a convention in the world,
A name and clan that is proclaimed;
It is agreed upon and comes together,
Proclaimed here and there.
For a long time it has been latent,🔽For one who does not know the view;
Not knowing, they proclaim,

original: jātiyā hoti brāhmaṇo.🔽Na jaccā brāhmaṇo hoti,
translated: By birth one is a brahmin.🔽One is not a brahmin by birth,
Nor by birth is one not a brahmin;
By action one is a brahmin,

original: kammunā hoti abrāhmaṇo.🔽Kassako kammunā hoti,🔽sippiko hoti kammunā;
analyzed: kammunā hoti abrāhmaṇaḥ  kassakaḥ kammunā hoti  sippikaḥ hoti kammunā
translated: By action one is not a brahmin.🔽By action one is a farmer,🔽By action one is a craftsman;
By action one is a merchant,

original: pessako hoti kammunā.🔽Coropi kammunā hoti,🔽yodhājīvopi kammunā;
analyzed: pessakaḥ hoti kammunā  coraḥ upi kammunā hoti  yodhājīvaḥ api kammunā
translated: By action one is a servant.🔽By action one is a thief,🔽By action one is a soldier;
By action one is a priest,

analyzed: rājā api hoti kammunā  evam etam yathā bhūta
translated: By action one is a king.
Thus the wise see action as it really is,
Seeing dependent origination,
Skilled in the ripening of kamma.
The world is ruled by kamma,
the world is born of kamma;
Beings are bound by kamma,
like the revolving wheel by the peg.
Through austerity and holy life,

analyzed: sayamena damena ca  etena brāhmaṇaḥ ha iti
translated: through self-control and restraint,🔽one becomes a brahmin,
this is the highest brahminhood.
Endowed with the three knowledges,
peaceful, his fetters destroyed,
thus, Vasettha, you should know
Brahma and Sakka, who know.

original: Evaṁ vutte, vāseṭṭhabhāradvājā māṇavā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte vāseṭṭha bhāradvājāḥ māṇavāḥ bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: When this was said, the brahmin students Vasettha and Bharadvaja said to the Blessed One:

original: “abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama.🔽Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa🔽vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti;
analyzed: abhikkanta bho gotama abhikkanta bho gotama  seyyathā api bho gotama nikkujjitam vā ukkujjeyya paṭicchannam vā vivareyya mūḷhassa  vā maggam ācikkheyya andhakāre vā tela pajjotam dhāreyya cakkhumantaḥ rūpāni dakkhanti iti
translated: “Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent, Master Gotama!

original: evamevaṁ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
analyzed: evam evam bhotā gotamena aneka pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito
translated: Master Gotama has made the Dhamma clear in many ways, as though he were turning upright what had been overthrown, revealing what was hidden, showing the way to one who is lost, or holding up a lamp in the dark for those with eyesight to see forms.

original: Ete mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
analyzed: ete mayam bhavantam gotamam saraṇam gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: “We go to Master Gotama for refuge and to the Dhamma and to the Sangha of bhikkhus.

original: Upāsake no bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gate”ti.
analyzed: upāsake naḥ bhavam gotamaḥ dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetam saraṇam gata iti
translated: May the venerable Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone to him for refuge, from this day forward, for life.”
The eighth sutta in the Vasettha Samyutta is finished.
